Choose a different color each time.  Output: 11<n><n>Input:Suppose that your dog runs away for 10 minutes, when she returns the dog is at the following location.  Choose the following options and give the correct answer after giving each.  * He is at a park B: restaurant/bars/etc C: office D: town E: school K: city<n>Output:<n><n>input = The name of a business/company/venue/etc., which is located in a town.<n>Output = The name of a company/venue/etc., located in a town.   Each time someone asks this question we get a new list of answers and there is a chance that the result looks like  (input1,output1,output2,output2,output3,output3,output4,output4,input5,output5).<n>Now suppose there are 12 such letters. Since there are 12 possibilities we get 10 choices - 10 possible answers.<n>Output = True if the answer selected is the correct answer.<n>Output = False if the answer selected is not the correct answer.<n><n>input = The location of a town. Output = The location of a company/venue /etc.<n>output = The name of a town. Each time someone asks this, the answer is different.<n>Input =The name of a business/co-locating/venue/etc.,which is located in a town<n>Output = The name a business/co-location/venue/etc.,  which is located in a  town....<n>Output = The name is named "company", place, business, or other business location.  If the name is in the list of potential matches, it is displayed.<n>Output = True (input1,output2, output2,output3, output3,output4,output4,output5,output5,input6,output6,output7,output7,output0,output0,output1,output1,input1,output1).<n>Output = False (input1,output3,output1,output3, output4, output4, output 5,output 5,output 5,input6,output 6,output 5,input7,input 7,output 7,output 0,output 0,output1,output 1,output1,input 1).<n>Output = True if

They are the same height, but we all do the same things differently. For reasons I know not yet, they were created differently.  I have no idea why this happened, and I doubt it is ever going to be explained.  It could be for one of two reasons.  1) The scientists were all women, so their decision to make girls different meant they had less sex, so sex was low on the list of priorities. 2) The scientists were all men, so their decision to create boys meant they could have kids, and more sex was high on the list of priorities, so sex was high on the priority list. I am not sure, maybe that is it.  I could find out.  Maybe someday.<n><n>This is just a short list of interesting facts about me, but there are much more. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Sitting to close while watching TV can cause what sort of pain? Choices:  A: brain problems B: laziness C: get fat D: headache E: laughter<n>Output:		 42 (34%) A B C E D<n><n>(3.8)  "I sat down close to the TV."<n><n>To answer you must do the following:  1.  Put your hands on the back of your knees and lie back.  Lean forward slightly so that your head is tilted to the left.  Lean your head and shoulders back to make room for your chest to fill the TV.<n>2.  Take deep breaths, hold them then exhale as you straighten up and move your neck.<n>3.  This helps to create breathing room and the motion helps your neck to move as though in a comfortable position.<n><n>NOTE: Ask students to answer this question when you have them watch a TV show.  If they sit near the TV and the show gives them the chance to sit closer toward the head, you may want to change one or more of the answers to questions 1-3 (note: I did not read the rest of page 4 to answer questions 1 - 3).<n><n>For a different exercise, let them watch a movie so that they can make up their own answers to questions 1-4 (note: I did NOT read this entire page and the above answers don't match the answers I did read for questions 1 - 3 in class.  I have not changed any of my answers.)<n><n>As a test, I also showed a movie with two very close ups.  I can ask students what they would have changed to change the answers.  Many might have made it "B" rather than "B" and some might have put the "R" at the end of "Brain Problems".  If many students made the changes, I'll grade that one differently than the others.

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Jamie wanted to reduce her waist size, but all of her efforts failed miserably.  She continued to do what? Choices:  A: gain weight B: augment C: dispare D: make larger E: expand<n>Output:		 44<n>### Explanation:<n>For Jamie's answer, she has to know the weight of each item in her basket. If Jamie has 7 items in her basket and loses 4 of them, her basket weight will be 12.  If Jamie loses 9 of the 7 items, her basket weight will rise to 18 and the 4 items will remain.<n>So Jamie needs to know the weight of the first 4 items before she can reduce the weight of the remaining 6 items.<n><n>Input:Mary has 12 stickers on her diary page.She uses 3 large stickers on the diary page and 6 stickers each to 4 other pages of her diary.How should Jamie's diary look like? Output: 44

(John 7:34)<n>Output: The spiritual side of man is discussed in Genesis. The spiritual side of faith is mentioned in Romans (Romans 3:21). Man has spiritual problems which God deals with through Jesus Christ (John 14:16). God will give us all things and we can choose which ones we will accept and which ones we won’t. The spiritual side of a person’s life is discussed in 1 Peter and Paul. Christians can have faith in God and he helps them with problems. The “in this world” and “the world to come” part of a statement of faith are discussed in the Bible. The “the one and only” part

Choices:  Dog  Horse  Mouse  Cat<n>Output: Cat  Mouse<n><n>A few rules for this. 1. You can only start with a correct answer. 2. You cannot choose the right answer with a combination of answers. 3. If a multiple choice question contains a 'False' answer, the correct answer will be chosen. 4. All multiple choice questions should begin with the sentence "a _____". 5. If a multiple choice answer contains more than 2 options, choose the answer closest to the true/false answer.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Bob's feet hurt from running barefoot on the hot pavement.  I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n>Output:		 36<n><n>Do these sentences, by themselves or combined with other sentences, have the same theme (useful, safe, correct, etc)?  Is there a meaningful link between them?  It's probably not as clean of an answer as you think it is.<n><n>Question: What is the meaning of the following sentence?<n>"I am a writer. A writer would have to write: 'If you're a teacher, you can't help a child with a fever.'"<n><n>Answer: The question asked for a response that "if you're a teacher, (insert your profession)," so my answer is what the teacher wrote.  The teacher is not criticizing Mary's choice of profession.<n><n>Question: Who is John the baker?<n>Answer: John was walking down a road, when a bee went down his throat.<n><n>In both of these sentences, the meaning is not specified.  Are they the same meaning because neither person is named in the sentence?  Are they different meanings because the speaker is not named in the second sentence?<n><n>Solution:<n><n>The answer to the first question is yes -- the meaning is unclear.  The answer to the second question is also yes -- again, the meaning is unclear -- either "a teacher" implies that the speaker is a teacher and therefore says that "John the baker" will answer the question about the bees' throat, and John is a baker, or "the baker was walking down a road," implies that John the baker works in a bakery so Mary didn't need to give the correct answer.<n><n>Now that we've worked out how to solve the two questions, let's see how we can answer the second question.<n><n>(A reader might ask what the reader thinks of the word "bakery" if it doesn't necessarily imply a particular type of baker. I see no reason why our readers would assume that.)

Then write down the value of the coin which is still in the stack. Write down the value for the coin being picked up in the round which is in the stack. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? Choices:  A: helicopter B: own cars C: speak words D: believe in god E: dance together<n>Output:		 24<n><n>How to make paper boats from toilet paper tubes and string<n><n>Hello everyone,<n>Last year I made a paper boat model my brother did with me and it lasted a couple of days. This year I wanted to make the model last a full day so I used a more modern approach. My brother has been playing with an 8mm polyester felt pen which is perfect for a model boat as the cardboard tubes that come with the pen bend and break easily after the first hit. To make a wooden boat, I started with cutting out 8 felt pen tubes from a sheet of polyester fibreboard. I glued a piece of paper towel to the bottom and cut out a circular hole by putting the felt tube in it. Then I used a 2×4 piece of wood as legs for the boat. I cut a slot into the bottom of the wood with a serrated razor blade to fit the felt tubes. I glued together the wooden legs and tied them together with bungee cords. Now I just cut a hole in the centre of the felt for the fuel tube from the small tube I glued to the bottom of the boat.<n>My son went out this afternoon and put a 2×4 piece as a support for the boat. As usual, he had no idea how everything works with my boat! Thank you for your help,<n>Holly
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What is an area with no grass where I can get things to sell at a roadside stand? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n>Output:		 What is an area with no tree where I will sell trees at roadside stands? Choices:  an area without trees B: wooded area C: open field D: forest<n><n>Solution:<n><n>Area with no grass: (10+1)2 or 1 where 10 is 1 or 10+1 where 1 is the value for area without grass, but this is not a valid area.<n>Area with no trees: (10+1)(5+4)2 or (2+2) where 5+4 is the value for trees and 4 is the number of stickers in place on 5 pages where 5 is the value for trees.<n>Area with no flower: (4+6)2 or (4+6)4 where 6 is the number of stickers used.<n>Area with no fruit: (10+2)3 or (10+3+3) where 10 is the number of stickers for fruit and 2 is the number of stickers that are used (not a valid area). Area with fruit and no tree: (4+5)2 or (4-5)4 where 5 is number 1 or 10+3 where 4-5 is number 2 and 5-4 is number 4 and 5 is the value of fruit +2.

Choices:  A: drill B: committed murder most vile C: bargemaster D: learn E: understand<n>Output:		 1 for every 3 choices<n><n>To answer your questions, first you must decide which crafts they are talking about.<n><n>1: A craft is an art based on objects.  An artistic process involves working from a creative, thoughtfulness, and skillfulness.  Crafts also refer to a process or manner of doing something creative.<n><n>2: Drilling can be a craft.  A master of the craft would have a deep understanding of the product, how to do it well, and how to improve it.  The master of a crafts skill will put in the work and effort to advance their skills.  A master of a crafting can find unique and innovative ways to produce something that can only be created on their own.<n><n>3: Committed Murder and Bargemaster refer to different crafts.<n><n>Note: If you answered D, the answer has always been B, and the answer that you picked will be the correct answer. If you answered A, the answer has always always always been C, and the answer that we gave you is wrong. If you answered E, the answer has always never been a D, and the answer that answered will always be E.<n><n>Please keep in mind that this game is not meant to be a real life game. Then, answer the "Questions" as simply as possible.<n>When you're done, try writing a sentence "Using" each of the questions.  Use the answer that you got in the fact box to answer each question. Output: 11.5%<n><n>Interpersonal Communication and Decision MakingInterpersonal Communication and Decision making is the process of interpreting cues that your partner gives to you. In interpersonal communication and decision making, the following cues are given: physical and non-physical cues, information about yourself and about the other person, and signals about how you’re feeling. The following decision making techniques were used while conducting research:<n><n>(1) Ask for an update on the situation.<n><n>(2) Listen carefully, for as long as you can, to your partner’s answers and comments. What can you hear? What can you see? These signs can give you valuable information about your partner’s thinking, especially if the information is important and there are no other clues.<n><n>(3) Observe your partner’s body language.<n><n>(4) Think through the situation at different times. It may be possible that a different partner is making the decision you’re considering.<n><n>(5) Compare your partner’s reactions with your own. What are your reactions?<n><n>(6) Consider your partner’s responses. Take a look at the situation. Are all the possibilities being considered? Does time seem to change the way you feel?<n><n>(7) Look at all your past experiences which may provide new information.<n><n>(8) Decide and consider your own behavior and feelings. You may get your answer about the situation from what your partner does or doesn’t do later.<n><n>The results of your research, using these

I have been struggling with the idea of using a straight line to show if there are two straight lines or only a single line. I am very new at calculus. Any help would be appreciated!<n><n>The solution is a single point. The point is where I intersect my straight line and I draw a horizontal line from the point to the horizontal. Now the two lines meet at a point.<n><n>You may think of the point as being at the horizontal as well. So you make the horizontal line to the left intersect the first line. Then you make a horizontal line parallel to these two lines to the right. You can do a triangle at the point. Then you draw a vertical line.<n><n>The point is where you intersect your straight line and you draw a horizontal line from there to a point. When two straight lines intersect the only thing you can do is take off an angle off one of them. Otherwise you just draw straight lines.<n><n>I would say only draw straight lines with that axis, but you can just use the point if you want to do that. You can still draw a triangle with the point in the triangle. It's just you don't think of it as being on the axis. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:How might people perceive someone they are scared of? Choices:  A: human B: happy C: dangerous D: strange E: weird<n>Output:		 B<n><n>This is an example of using the Averager–Meader Scale, a model for human social interactions.<n><n>1. The Averager Scale allows people to estimate each other's emotions based on a range of emotions from happy to very upset.<n><n>2. People perceive others on a scale of 1 to 5 with emotional range from happy to very upset<n><n>3. In person, people say how people they are scared of seem to them.<n><n>4. When people are afraid of someone, it is often helpful to them to understand what is happening on the other side of their fear.<n><n>5. This model can teach you about the basic human emotions of anger, happiness, terror and disgust.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What happens when someone is playing too aggressively? Choices:  A: get hungry B: laughter C: injury D: having fun E: feeling happy<n>Output:		  A - if the person does not want aggression they should have more respect for others<n>B - if the person does want aggression they should not say it or tell others to be quiet or take it easy. If someone is doing a form of aggression, this is not their fault. C - if the person does get angry, the should not talk about it or get angry and then lash out at someone and act aggressive towards them or someone else. D - if the person becomes angry, it is a completely different scenario because they should not act aggressive towards anyone<n>E - a situation like this is very different of who to choose. A - the more you get angry then the more difficult it is for others to not become angry<n><n>Your results:<n>A - if the person does try to be friendly they should not be afraid to be friendly, a person can be friendly at the same time as being aggressive. B - if the person does become aggressive they should not have aggressive tendencies towards others. C - if the persone does want to be friendly, they should not be scared or feel like they have to be apologetic to everyone in order to receive kindness. D - if the persone wants to be friendly, they would have to work more towards becoming friendly rather than acting aggressive towards others<n>E - in situations like these, it is better to choose A to be aggressive then E to be friendly, because by being aggressive in A's scenario, they are going to push down the other person by giving them a rude comment. So because of this, A would become angry with people and it could become dangerous.<n><n>The best answer wins!<n><n>You must include an answer that fits the question.

Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n>Output:		 40<n><n>Which of the following will best illustrate the concept of a self-correcting algorithm? A self correcting algorithm will recognize that the value of a number n is increasing if the value of its first digit is increasing or decreasing if the value of its second digit is increasing. A self-correcting algorithm will recognize that a number n is decreasing if the value of n's first digit is decreasing or increasing if it's value of second digit is decreasing. A self-corrective algorithm will recognize that a n can be changed to a smaller number if it has an infinite number of decimals. A self-correcter will recognize that an n can be changed to an infinity number if it can be multiplied by a value of n less than n.<n><n>Input:Mary bought 88 carrots. A. A. 0 B. B. C. D. C. A<n><n>Input: Mary has 60 carrots. She gives each carrot to a different person, who in turn dishes 25 different carrots to 5 other people. C B A D<n>Output: 50<n><n>Which of the three following statements could be true? A. A positive number can’t have a negative number, B. A positive number can be divided by an infinite number of positive numbers, C. A positive number can never have a negative number, D. A positive number cannot have a negative number, but also do not have a positive number.<n><n>Input:A number is positive if every single digit is a positive number.A positive number will never have a negative number; a negative number can have a positive number, B a positive number can never have A positive number or B positive number, but never A negative number, C a positive number can always have a positive number but will never be a negative number, D a positive number

You can use the math below to get answers for this question.<n><n>2 = 4 3 = 8 4 = 10 5 = 13 8 = 19<n><n>Which sticker should she use to cover a page?<n><n>Answer:  Use the math above and you can find out which sticker for this question.<n>How many stickers does she have left? 24.<n><n>What is a small sticker?<n><n>Answer: Small stickers are 4 stickers or less.  Example:  Using the math below, you can find out:<n>5 x 4 = 15 3 x 8 = 23 2 x 2 = 13 12 x 4 = 33<n>24 x 10 = 72<n><n>A large sticker is: 5 stickers or larger. For example:  Using the math above, you can get the answer for this question.  14 x 5 = 39 11 x 6 = 60 17 x 5 = 74 19 x 9 = 94<n><n>What is one large sticker and 5 small stickers?<n><n>Answer: 1 large sticker is the sticker on the bottom right corner, and 5 small stickers are the sticker on the bottom left corner.<n><n>The master control for the doctor is near the top of the book cover. What is the largest sticker on the cover?

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n>Output:		 19<n><n>The following is a list of questions:<n>Input:  A: sun  B: sky C:  candle D:  house E: lamp<n> Output:  A:  sun  B:  sky  C:  candle  D:  house<n><n>This is a simple multiple choice.  We must determine the total cost of the questions, subtract from the total cost the value from the sticker sheet (minus any discounts), then we multiply the total cost by the number of required stickers to make the answer equal to the true number of stickers.  The number of stickers does NOT need to use the total sticker sheet.

The "correctly answer" button can be used on this activity at the end of the lesson.<n><n>"Homework Assignment:<n>Select the following statement based on information provided:<n>(1. It is a fact that most of the time people who commit a criminal act are found guilty of the crime)<n>(2. Therefore, it is reasonable for most people to assume that they would be guilty of any similar or worse crimes if they were given the chance.)<n>(3. Therefore, people who commit murder are worse than people who commit other crimes.) "<n><n>The task "Input: Fill in the blank" is not part of any lesson. However you may put "Homework" in your student's writing or do it yourself.<n><n>Your assignment is to answer the following multiple choice question;<n><n>Input: How many stickers did Mary have left of the 89 stickers she had been given?<n>Output: 14 stickers<n><n>This activity was based loosely on the "Answer the following questions" activity the "Sample" page. How can these two variables be used to draw a vertical line on a graph?<n>input: Why would I do a "Point Pivot(Int)(Ax2,Ax2)-Point Pivot(Int)"?<n>output: If I wanted to draw an arrow, I would have to "Point Pivot(Ax2,x)(Ax2,-x)"<n><n>Input: What type of function is used when you take two numbers and produce a number between those two numbers which is the square root of the number?<n>output: The

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Which effect of stress could cause death if not treated immediately? Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n>Output:		<n><n>Input: Which effect of stress could cause pain if not treated immediately?<n>Output: a broken heel or a broken toe D: swelling<n><n>Answer: A: a broken heel or broken toe<n><n>Question 6<n><n>Input: Which of the following has been the main cause of death in past years? Choices: a heart attack B: heart attack C: stroke D: suicide<n>Output: a heart attack E: heart attack<n><n>Input: Which impact of stress could cause death?<n>Output: A: heart attacks B: strokes C: suicide D: suicide<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>Assignment<n><n>We should also work on writing these assignments. Students can create a research page in their journal with as many as five pieces of information. Students can then research the topics provided on the research page in their journal and write as many or as few reports for their assignment as they would like.<n><n>In the first paragraph, each student should explain his or her sources of information, what sources did they use in their research, their conclusions, what the data was for their conclusions, etc. This helps the teacher assess who writes the best.<n><n>In the third paragraph, each student should also discuss:<n><n>1. what was the first thing that the student did after reading (and/or thinking about) their assignment<n>2. did the first student use the main information in the assignment (or all of the information in the assignment), what information did he/she use in their report, what conclusions did he/she use, how did she or he summarize the result, etc<n><n>2. is the student’s work helpful OR would it be helpful?<n><n>Do they give more information than we need? Is it only important to read/look at the first page of the paper or will the student’s research expand/deeper into your research?<n><n>Once the assignments are complete, we can assign them to the research group. For example, let’s say that we assign a “Sustained Stress Hypnosis Model” article and we want to see if their research and/or conclusion would be helpful. If student’s research is found helpful, let’s ask them if they could expand the idea (i.e. change the title or start using “stress hypothesis” instead of “sustained stress” model). If the student could not expand the idea, we would probably move on to the next question

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Where might a yard be tiny? Choices:  A: farmland B: neighborhood C: city D: property E: subdivision<n>Output:		 5<n><n>Input:A table with a single row shows 2 sets of ________ numbers. They are $0.00, $0.50, $0.75, $0.80, and $0.90. Pick the first number.    Output: 9<n><n>Input:You play cards in a deck with 7 columns, 3 rows, and 4 columns. Pick a column from the top row to start an unordered deck. What number card is in that row? Input: 3 Output: 5<n><n>Input and Output<n><n>Input and output should clearly describe what is happening in a word processor. When your child writes more than the minimum word length, you'll find yourself scratching your head. There's always room to readjust, but we want to keep the reader's interest.<n><n>Use the following word limit questions to introduce the vocabulary that will be taught in the coming weeks.<n><n>1. How many of your books does Michael have?<n>2. When does he eat his lunch and where does he stay the night?<n>3. How much time do you spend writing each day?<n><n>For information only.<n><n>Please help support the program by reading the full review or asking any questions in the forum!

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n>Output:		 6<n><n>1 Answer<n>1<n><n>Your problem isn't as difficult to answer as it seems. A microphone boom in a stock market event is in front of the camera (as you know for cameras) and is likely to be covering the sound of the event. Now, if a sound does happen on the camera and is masked by a microphone boom then either the camera operator did it himself (i.e. the stock traders do it) or a sound company has set up the boom for the event and it's likely that it's on-set. However, there is no reason for us to suppose that a sound company does it, so your answer will have to say something similar to the answer of #8.<n><n>So the questions asks you to take a guess at which way the boom was used as a mask for the sound. To answer the question correctly, you need to go back to the first sentence of the question and count all of the stickers on any page of Mary’s journal up to the end that’s still stickers. You only need to count seven stickers because the question only asks us to count how many stickers are still on any page, and there are only seven pages in total. So, for example, suppose there are only five stickers and a sixth sticker is on Mary’s first page. Then Mary has 89 stickers left. Given her total number of stickers, that means there are 89 stickers on the first page. Since we only count stickers we see on pages, that means that there are 89 stickers on page one on average, and there are 89 stickers on every page after that. That means there must be eight stickers after page one that are still stickers on average, and there must be five stickers on pages two through nine that are still stickers on an average page. So you need to say that there must be eight stickers remaining after page one because there are still 9 stickers on first page.<n><n>The more challenging part is answering the question about the location and shape of the microphone boom, and since we’re only given the numbers that the questions gives us we have only two possibilities:<n><n>either the microphone boom is located behind a camera (which, because you know cameras are often mounted on or above a camera tripod) is in front of the stock market scene (which means we should find how the stock market scene is changing) or<n><n>in front of the stock market is in the middle behind a camera (which means we should come up with how the stock market

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What is someone unintentionally hurting someone else but unable to stop likely to feel? Choices:  A: empowering B: regret C: despair D: glee E: sadness<n>Output:		 Empowerment, regret, glee, sadness, despair<n><n>This one is pretty easy. The solution is to just make it like the previous one : "The person who was unintentional hurt was able to stop".<n><n>Thanks for posting this, we used these multiple choice questions in our class. All of our students chose glee. The solution to both is empowering. Both ways of thinking about the activity are empowering, though.<n><n>How about this?<n><n>Input: Mary has 89 stickers. She uses 3 large stickers on the back cover and 7 stickers on 6 other pages of her diary. She has used 2 large stickers on the front cover and 7 large stickers on 6 other pages. Mary has left at least 4 large stickers on each of the back cover and front of her journals. How many stickers does she have remaining?<n><n>Output: 43 (all on pages)<n>There is a single large sticker on each the first five pages. On number 6 and 9 we don't know where the other stickers left to go. However, there is one large sticker on page 4.<n>We need to know if she has used 4 large stickers on any single page or if she has used 4 that weren't large.<n>We need an equation to solve.<n><n>Input: what is someone unintentionally hurting someone and unable to stop likely to do? Choices: C: regret E: glee D: despair F: glee E: despair<n>Output: Empowering, regret E, glee<n><n>This is really tricky. She put "glee" on top and under "despair" after each choice, so her options are still C, D and E. We get the opposite answer, as well as your answer. What's going on here? Are your options the same? The correct answer is despair, but it's not clear if the alternative is glee or glee.<n><n>You may say that the other answer is wrong and it should be in the negative, but there's nothing wrong with C or D (or E), as those choices are also empowering.<n><n>To go along with the multiple choice questions, you might want to include these in the solution:<n><n>Output: What is someone unintentionally hurting someone who has no control over, is unaware of, or incapable of stopping likely to feel? Chooses: C: Glee (Glee is the only thing that could have prevented Glee, and should have been Glee). E: Despair (Despair is the

It’s about a boy who can play on his own for some time and then a group of girls in another class want to play with him. They go down to his desk and find out that he has a really big toy dinosaur next to his desk. After they play with that toy for some time they ask him to play with them, but so far he doesn’t know what to do: he can’t seem to pick a favorite thing and his hands are getting tired! After some of the girls leave he sees a man coming in his direction, but first he shouts his name from a distance: “HEY! WHO ARE YOU?” The man is the guy from class before, he is looking very surprised because this isn’t what he expected to see. Then the man explains to them how the dinosaur was made, how it was a gift from friends and how it belongs to a museum in Rome, so they can still play with it. And after they leave the dinosaur comes to life, it starts to move its back legs a lot: "It’s alive!" "Why is it moving like that?" The boy is shocked, "Does it have to?” he says and looks at the dinosaur even more attentively! The man tells him that all those movements mean that it needs water and the boy has to bring it back to life to get water from outside. The boy, who doesn’t seem to understand what he is going to do, rushes off to ask his mom if he can bring the dinosaur back to life because he needs to go to the zoo and this toy is so important to him. It took him about 5 minutes until his mother comes to the window, picks up the dinosaur and returns it to him.<n><n>I don’t have any posters either. It's hard to assign only 5 options without looking at it too carefully. I suppose "afternoon" and "early evening" are obvious. They just seem easier choices? Over time, I'd expect you to get a little better at making these sorts of choices, but maybe a little at the same time? Who knows? It will probably happen if you keep at it.<n><n>The second section on choices seems a lot easier than the first. I think this is due in part to the fact that there are already several options. The next time you do these there will probably be some more choices and this should make the second section easier.<n><n>Another way to think about problems like these is that the number of points your given to a question will increase with the difficulty of the test. The second are adjectives.<n>C. The third are interjections.<n>D. The fourth are prefixes.<n>E. The fifth are prepositions.<n><n>A. A sentence.<n>B. A sentence with a verb after the preposition<n>C. One day there was a large snow storm (D). Explain how the house lost its roof (A).

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n>Output:		  B C D<n><n>I'm trying to see if there's any other way to have something like this work (for example, in the original version you can't use "A" and "B" together.)<n><n>It's not hard, just requires good judgment. If you have enough information (the number of sticker pages and the number of stickers in the case) then it shouldn't be that hard.<n><n>Sorry, this is supposed to go elsewhere...<n>How does your question work? There's no way for me to know how many stickers Mary has left since I've never printed her journal.<n><n>The question is asking for an output.<n>It should be possible to provide numbers from input.<n><n>The problem with your question is that the answer is completely arbitrary, and that's the whole point of doing problems like this. What you should probably be doing is asking the questions<n>How many stickers is Mary likely to have? how many are left? and asking for the last few stickers to the most likely answer. The answer is still entirely arbitrary, though (since people will answer differently).<n>The point of the problem isn't to answer accurately, just to provide a few useful tools for answering what question to ask next.<n><n>It feels like your question is asking for arbitrary answers that are arbitrarily subjective. It's like you're forcing us to guess things based on how the questions work.<n>I do agree that there's no way to figure out what the correct answer is. Maybe what I'm expecting is too obvious. I should have said 'if a person wants to guess.' I'm sure a lot will guess 'three,' but that would just be wrong on the answer.<n><n>The point of the question is not arbitrary, but rather to make the person answer the question. Of course, the answer is going to be either 'A' or 'B,' or 'C'. In any case, most of the stickers are still in Mary's journal, so the answer to the question is still 'Three'. Any further questions I could ask are pointless.<n>For what it's worth, the original question asked for the number of pages not used stickers; however, I think the original question implied that there would be an answer that could be described as "Nine stickers." That answer was wrong, since there's nothing in the answer.

We vote for the person. Well, first, the popular vote doesn't mean that much in Canada. Only 26,000,000 people voted in the last Canadian election. So, you have a choice in Canada. You can vote for a politician. They get votes from a district and that district votes. Then they are voted in as a senator or a deputy leader. Then they would work with people and get bills passed. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What happens to people when they do not have enough food? Choices:  A: eat fish B: they steal C: talk to each other D: write stories E: die of starvation<n>Output:		 N/A<n><n>Answers:<n><n>A: They eat fish because the fish have no money B: They steal because they lack self control C: They talk to each other D : talk to yourself E : die a quick death of starvation<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>The answer above has five components. The first three components are given in the answer to a previous task. The fourth component is an answer in the answer to a future one. In this example the fourth component is an answer to a future one of the 5 questions posed in this lesson.<n><n>To answer the future question, the answer from the first question is made the fourth component:<n><n>Input: Mary has 14 stickers. She ate 9 stickers and 3 stickers and 3 stickers. With 13 stickers left, how many stickers does she have remaining?<n>Output (from earlier in this lesson) - 44<n><n>Input: What happened to people when they did not have enough food? A: they became desperate and hungry. B: they stopped eating. C: they made food to survive. D: most people decided to write stories instead of eating. E: no one ate because there were no stories left to eat.<n>Output (from earlier this lesson) - 40<n><n>Answers: B, D, and E tell the same story. The only thing that has changed is the question and the answer. In D answers can exist in many of the 5 parts of the lesson. Answers for the first two parts are the third in the first part of the story; questions can exist in E, 1, 4, 7, or any combination thereof.<n><n>To answer parts 4 and 5 of the story, the answer from B is made the fourth component for part 4 "Write a story" and also for the 5th question "Talk to each other"

Input:  What's the sign language the girl is holding in her hands while telling us what a big deal this is?  Will you sign this?<n>Output: 46<n><n>Name: Tanya. Age 6. Home: Momma’s and a little piece of Daddy. Grade School: 3rd grade Language: English, Spanish Sign Language: Lingo. Activity: When you are driving home what do you have to do to avoid accidents or have a fun drive?  What can we do to avoid accidents?  How can you prevent accidents?  What can you do to have fun without using your head?  Can you sign what is said before, during and after a trip?  How do you use your head when you are in a hurry?  Can you tell what an event is in a movie?  How can you sign the words?  How can you talk in the car without making the other person think you talk?  What is the sign language of the sign for “Don’t talk”?   I ask for the teacher.  I get the question.  I write Tanya down.  Then I come up with her problem, “Name one sign language of the sign (the last one is your own) that means “don’t have a car accident’ and write it down.”  Then I ask for the teacher and he gives the student five minutes to give me the answer.  I get the answer.  Tanya has been given another set of points.  The teacher does not sign that word up.  “What you think he did is a bad behavior.”<n><n>Name: John D. Age 26. Home: Mommas, and a very little piece of Daddy.  Grade School: 1st grade Language: English, German, Russian, and a little bit of his own French Sign Language: Lingo and a little bit of her own Spanish Language: Sign language of all languages. Activity: Which of the following do you think is the best sign language of its kind?  Write one or two sentences with the language you are using together and give me an answer by saying with the sign language

The man said, "I don't want a regular birth control, I want some kind of special birth control."  The doctor said, "No special birth control, just take regular birth control, because that's the best birth control."   The man said, "...I want to start a family, and I want to do it right. I don't want to use any kind of birth control except regular birth control."    How many children did the man have?<n>Output: 2<n><n>Input: there is a tree at work. One is locked up. What is the answer to this question?<n>Output: 50

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:He curled up and tried to fall on his shoulder so his arm or what wouldn't take the hit? Choices:  A: leg B: garment C: torso D: body E: road<n>Output:		 A: leg<n><n>The first question is multiple choice (10 points for correct answers) and the second and third questions are each one-choice questions (7 points for correct answers). The fourth question is a question of type "which" (6 points for correct answers). It is meant to test your knowledge of which clothing items were involved in the first three questions.<n><n>Remember that the more clothes a person is wearing in one category, the more likely they are to "cover up" rather than move around, eat, or use objects in other categories. You'll see this later in the lesson.<n><n>"Fancy" clothes were usually worn by children, such as jackets and pants, to protect them and keep them warm.<n><n>If you chose a choice A option then the answer would be a choice B option, if only wearing clothing B options were being considered.<n><n>If you selected a choice C option then you would be asked to select (1-3) alternatives before you answer the first question of the lesson. However, your choice C options may not be the best choice for all your questions, so remember this when giving your answer to the first question.

Does that have any bearing on the game?<n><n>#### Answer. 1) Mary did not purchase a hairbrush in the drugstore and did not purchase a bandage in the hospital. It is assumed that she used the same bandage on all of her papers. 2) Mary made 3 large stickers and 3 small stickers on each page of her journal. She finished with one large sticker on each page. She has used 7 stickers total to cover all of her papers. She has finished with one large sticker at the front of her journal and another large sticker on the right side of her journal. All 3 large stickers have been used. 3) Mary did not purchase 3 bandages in the hospital. It was assumed that she used the large stickers to cover all of her paper work. 4) Mary purchased 6 large stickers in the drugstore and 2 small stickers in the hospital. She only purchased 2 small stickers in the bedroom and finished her journal with one large sticker on the front of the journal and a small sticker at the right side of her book. 5) Mary did not purchase 2 large stickers in the drug store. It was assumed that Mary used the large stickers and bandages to cover all of her documents. 6) Mary did not purchase an extra large sticker in the drugstore because she did not finish with a large one in the hospital. 7) Mary did not use 7 stickers total for her papers because 1) it had been a long time since she used 7 stickers (she had a total of 2), 2) her journal was already covered with one large sticker, and 3) she finished her journal with a large sticker. 8) Mary used 5 stickers in the drugstore to cover her journal so she finished with 1 large sticker from the store on the right side. 9) Mary did not use 5 stickers total for her papers, but completed with a large sticker at the front.<n><n>#### In a classroom, on a white board, the teacher wants to give each child a chance at a prize. Each time the choice is offered, the first person who wants to move and offer a choice has to choose another. This activity will enhance the lesson and help her develop her cognitive skills.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What animal produces milk? Choices:  A: supermarket B: pig C: cow D: refrigerator E: store<n>Output:		 What animal does not produce milk? Choices: A: donkey B: sheep C: dog D: horse E: cow<n>Output: What animal produces milk<n><n>Select two out of the following to write down:<n><n>1. If an animal does not produce milk, it does not produce food and cannot survive.<n><n>2. If an animal does produce milk, its milk is not a staple food.<n><n>3. If a cow does not produce milk, its milk does not produce food, and it has high chances of killing its own offspring.<n><n>4. If a donkey does not produce milk, milk does not produce food for any of its offspring, and it cannot survive.<n><n>5. If a camel does not produce milk, and milk does not produce food and does not kill its own offspring, then milk is used as food and the camel cannot survive.<n><n>Select three out of these to write down:<n>- Why do cows milk their offspring?<n><n>- How can a cow produce milk without producing food?<n>- Why does a camel produce milk?<n><n>Answer all three questions.<n><n>1) Do not select two out of the following:<n><n>A) She can use food<n>B) She can't use food<n>C) She feeds her offspring<n>D) She needs food<n>E) She lives<n><n>2) If a cow does not milk her offspring, then the milk is not a staple or healthy food for cows, and it is therefore wasted food and cannot be used.<n><n>3) If a camel doesn't produce milk and milk doesn't kill its own offspring, milk is used as food, and so the camel can survive.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n>Output:		 42<n><n>Your answer is incorrect - there are 3 correct answer choices.<n><n>Correct answer choices are:<n><n>A:  Short term<n>B:  Crowd<n>C:  unpredictable<n>D:  frequent<n>E: Eternal<n><n>In this set of questions and answers, you see a common theme - how is society defined and defined when it is used for good? When people use the secular parties to have fun or in some cases to escape from personal difficulties, is God's definition of society always true? God could never be used to justify this behavior. The world is a very violent world and society is full of bad actors - it is sometimes easier to use secular parties as a temporary escape. This is a common theme that Christians have a hard time accepting because it means the very idea of God is being rejected.<n><n>So, what do you do about this? I suggest you make a habit of turning secular parties into something for God's sake. Many secular party organizers want to help atheists or agnostics and want us to have a great time. They want us to have a good time and that is okay. We should be celebrating the secular parties for the secular parties themselves - they are just that - events that occur with people for the sake of having a good time. We don't need to make it more than that - we only need to make it better.<n><n>So, is society a place we can use God as an excuse while still enjoying secular parties? Why? Because we are in the presence of the One who is always with us in our moments of need. People who believe that life is fragile and that sin is always a bad thing have no basis in God so why should we expect him to be there to help us if we need help?<n><n>So as we celebrate secular parties as an opportunity to have fun, make sure to celebrate it for someone else as well.

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What would cause someone to use invitro for reproducing? Choices:  A: problems B: offspring C: overpopulation D: larger family E: baby<n>Output:		 3<n><n>Input: The following is a list of the parts of the human body. At least of four or more of these items will be found on a person's body according to the most common explanation provided from the literature.  For example:  1. Chest: 6 organs 2. Heart: arteries 4 chest tubes 3. Armpit: livers 4. Throat: bronchal tubes 5. Testicle: testis 6. Belly: kidneys<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: What will always be on the brain?  How will it always be on the brain according to the most common opinion from the literature?<n>Output: 2<n><n>This problem uses 5 objects. The answers are in the boxes below.<n>The solution should correspond in part to what the author says. I've tried to write an example of the author's explanation on the bottom of the box.<n><n>Example from the book I will use.<n>The human body consists of an exterior shell, a core, a brain, and some vital tissue. The brain is the most vital component. It has vital functions that help coordinate the movement and control of muscles and organs, and it produces all kinds of chemicals and nutrients in order to sustain these vital activities. The brain also creates and regulates an environment which guides the movements of the body, and which in turn helps regulate the movements of the whole body. The brain's structure and function can be studied using the same techniques of surgery as one of the organs (see the section on cranial surgery) and can be used to diagnose and perhaps even to repair diseases. But the brain is not simply the organ of thought, speech, and movement, which is the usual and often preferred medical image of it. The brain is an organ that carries information from the body, and hence can represent abstractions in a way the other organs do not.<n><n>Example from another book I will use:<n>Every child wants to fit in. Being different is an everyday occurrence that adults tend to ignore, unless, of course, they are the ones of the minority or are dealing with a person with a particular disability or abnormality.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n>Output:		 What is the opposite of foolish? Choices:  B: careless A: foolish C: careful D: cautious E: cautious<n><n>When you are completing questions 1, 2, and 3 (and other questions like this) in the middle of the workbook, you must choose which of the following answers will help you the most:<n><n>Answer 1: Foolhardy is clever but foolish is foolish and wise. You can show your thinking about all these options by looking carefully and carefully trying to pick the answer that your teacher will like best (don't forget not to guess right!). Try answering multiple choice questions on the board, then do the same for questions 1 and 2 (and other answers like this) in the workbook.<n><n>Answer 2: It's foolish to put stickers on the front of a document that cannot be removed later. You must put stickers on the front page (in front of the covers) in all your journal papers. You can put any type of stickers on the front page, but you must use them on the front of the paper. You can put small stickers all around your page, but any stickers that you put on the front end are stuck to your paper. For smaller or bigger stickers there are three options available, depending on whether you choose the front or back of your paper. You will usually see that there is another option near the bottom of each sticker which says "Back" or "Front," but there might be no choice if you are a student with both back and front stickers!<n><n>Answer 3: Wise people take a lot of risks but Foolhardy people make fools of themselves. Wise folks always have an exit plan; foolish will never be caught by surprise. The person who answers questions 1, 2 and 3 correctly is the wisest person in the class.<n><n>When questions 4, 5 and 6 come up try these options to figure out what you want to know. Note the options near the bottom of each of the stickers which has "Back" or "F.A." (see the above answer to question 3):<n><n>Answer 4:Foolhardy may be wise but Foolish does not. The person who answers question 4 correctly will tell you they were right and that is the answer you need. This answer is sometimes the easy right answer, but not always. A wise person who does not answer question 4 correctly will tell a wrong answer and you would have a very hard time finding that out on your own.<n><n>You may find that you chose

This is an example of teaching real life.<n><n>The correct answer is 1 sticker remained on the front page of Mary's journal.<n>The incorrect answer is 2 stickers remained on the front page.<n>The correct answer is 4 stickers remained on the front of Mary's journal. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:If you're speaking to a lawyer about getting a divorce, what relationship status are you trying to end? Choices:  A: being married B: sisters C: marriage D: two people E: lawyer<n>Output:		 lawyer with sisters<n><n>It is expected that all questions submitted to Answers will be of correct and honest character. The question in this lesson was based on a correct but honest response. The other questions were based on a questionable response. There is no way to make this question less ambiguous or to make it more honest.<n>To provide you with a fair evaluation, Answers has allowed your class to rate each question and to choose from the top 100 questions. You have the opportunity to decide the best rating for your question.<n><n>Questions:<n>1. If you are married it is expected that you will start with A<n>2. If you are not married it is expected that the answer to A would be B<n>3. If you start out on B you will not end up with the same answer to the next one. For example, if you answer B,C and then you answer D, you go back to having C and not having something else. If you answer D it will be B<n>4. You should use something in the beginning of your sentences and I believe this is right so use __________.<n>5.If you have __________ you should use it in the beginning of your name but if it has no effect then you should not.<n>6.There are 7 words in a sentence. It makes it seem like you are writing paragraphs so you should not have to use paragraphs. For example, if there are 7 words in your sentence then you can use three paragraphs.<n>7.There are 4 kinds of writing. It makes it sound like you are only writing two of them so you should write more. For example, if your question is about how to write a paragraph you should write the first 4 or 5 paragraphs in the question that are the best and then the last paragraph in the question that may be the best.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. If the dollar is easy to get out of without breaking, there is no point in having a bank.<n><n>Answer: #3<n><n>Quote:<n><n>The only way I can think of for a dollar to get inside an envelope would have to be a zipper. Zippers could be manipulated by anyone as long as they had the zipper mechanism. They could also be glued on the inside. However, I could see someone with lots of practice zipping on the outside of envelopes, but I would think it would be a fairly complex technique.<n><n>What do you think? Could it also be an easy way to get a dollar out of the envelope?<n><n>It could, assuming that the secret is to open the envelope and insert the dollar. (ie, you need to open your envelope first)<n><n>Quote:<n>They could also be glued onthe inside for easy access, but how do they make that an appealing technique? I don't think people would like it.<n><n>Well, they could be made to be easily removed if/when needed. I personally do not like zippers (don't ask!). They can be easily removed by cutting them (a little like the way people remove stickers from the edge of their envelope).<n><n>Quote:<n>I could see someone with lotsof practice zipping on theoutside ofenvelopes, but I wouldthink it would be a fairly complicated technique.<n><n>Depends on how many envelopes they have. If it is many envelopes, a zipper might be a good design to use, but if it's just one, cutting is probably the best way to do it. In my mind, if your main concern is a zipper on the outside, the best option is to have a zipper on the inside and glue in place for easy removal. If the key is to open the envelope yourself, then you want to keep the envelope sealed and keep the money inside.<n><n>Quote:<n>There could be an easier way like a button on the inside?<n><n>This is not possible. Zippers do not have buttons on them.<n><n>Quote:Zippers could also beglued onthe inside for easyaccess. I don'tthink people would like it.Well, they could bemade to be easilyremoved if/when needed.<n><n>The only way people would get annoyed with this technique is if it is obvious that they are doing this. If it is not obvious and the person

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What appliance uses water and soap? Choices:  A: washing machine B: space shuttle C: blender D: disneyland E: surface of earth<n>Output:		 0<n><n>#### Response:Answer the following multiple question questions.<n><n>Input:  What is the definition of an 'emergent' system or a 'concurrent' system?<n>Output:  1<n>2<n>3<n>4<n>5<n>6<n><n>#### Response :The emergent system is the system which has a high level of activity and the concurrent system is the one which has a low level of activity.<n><n>#### Response #:Output: The emergent system has more events than the concurrent system. And the concurrent system has less events than the emergent system.<n><n>#### Responses #:Output: 1/1. The emergent system has higher number of events than the concurrent system and less events than the concurrent system, whereas the concurrent system has higher number of episodes compared to both the emergent and the concurrent systems.<n><n>#### #:Output:  For the emergent system. This question is not possible. The emergent system must have higher number of events than any other system and lower number of episodes than any other system.<n><n>#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<n><n>## What is the best time of year to go to a museum or a historical site? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What country has with the capital of Amsterdam has a Fortis bank? Choices:  A: netherlands B: utrecht C: brussels D: belgium E: denmark<n>Output:		 NEGOTIABLE<n><n>Answer:<n><n>This question is easy for many students to answer. If you have a limited source of facts then you can use these facts to support your answer. Use your own facts or facts in another class.<n><n>In the first question (which has 2 choices) all of them are correct.<n><n>Example:<n><n>When you get the information on the front side of the paper you do not use your own facts, you simply use the source at the bottom. Now you have a list of facts for this question. Next, when you use the source at the top you can find another list of facts. By doing this you can make your answer more easily. You can also make your answer more easily from multiple choices.<n><n>To help you remember, here is an example of questions with multiple choices:<n><n>The first question tells about a car, the second one is about a house and the third one is about a car. Here is the meaning of the question:<n><n>The first part of the question tells if the house and the car are real. The answer is “no” and “yes” for the first question and the answer is “yes” and “no” for the next question. When you use the source at bottom, now you know the name of the house and the car, you have the answer to the next question “Which of these are real?. If you know these names then you know the house and the car. That’s the purpose of source at bottom.<n><n>The second part of the question tells about the street. The answer is ” yes” and “ no”. It’s the same as the first part of the answer and also your knowledge the first part of answer. This part of the answer tells about the street too. So, you know the street and you know the house.<n><n>The third part of the question tells you the street and about the house and the house and when you use the source you know about the street and the house. With the street you know about the house about and the house is the house of yours.<n><n>So the answer to the question is : the answer is“yes”” yes to the house and the street(yes to real) and the answer is“no”” no to the street(the house is real) and the house(the house).

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:A shop will give you what for your purchases? Choices:  A: downtown area B: container C: ocean floor D: the lost city of atlantis E: high school<n>Output:		 B<n><n>### Answer: C<n><n>I would like to see each answer posted in the comments.<n><n>This Week's Questions<n><n>### How many of the following are correct?<n>1. Mary had 89 stickers. 2. Mary counted the 4th (bigger) sticker on the front of her journal as 4 because it is smaller than most stickers. 3. Mary then counted the 6 other stickers to the front of her journal for that page as she counted those. She then counted the 4th sticker at the beginning of the 5th page. 4. Mary counted the 2 smallest stickers on both the front and back of her journal.<n>5. How many stickers did Mary subtract from 89? 6. How many stickers does she begin with? Answer: 10.<n><n>### How many stickers does Mary begin with? Answer: 30.<n><n>### How high is the stack of stickers on the right side of the page?<n>Answer: 22.<n><n>### How long do all the stickers on the stack on the left side of the page take to get to the top of the stack? Answer: 18.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Where would a ficus plant brighten up a room? Choices:  A: middle east B: palace C: dictionary D: pots E: apartment<n>Output:		 55<n><n>Input/Output:  Which is most important when making a gift?  A: money B: time C: quality D: personal note E: food F: clothes<n>Output: 15<n><n>Input:  A and B share the same birthday. Which two things do they do on their birthdays? A: go camping B: go shopping C: go fishing D: go out to eat<n>Output: 9 and 13<n><n>Input: The first time Mary went to the doctor, she said to the doctor, "Hello doctor, my name is Mary."  The doctor replied, "You are from Philadelphia, correct?  Hello!"  Mary replied, "I am from New York, correct?"  The doctor replied,  Hello!  Mary's mother walked in during the doctor's response.  She turned the doctor's face to Mary, "Hello!"  After they finished, Mary said to her mother, "I want my dad to be my doctor. You get rid of the doctor and we all three go!"  She had just left her bedroom after putting on her "I am from New-York" outfit.  Her mother replied, "Mary wants your dad to be her doctor, too?"  Mary replied, "Yes. I want my dad to be a doctor and a ficus plant!"  This prompted her grandmother to go and ask, "Mary, what would the ficus plant do for you?"  Mary replied,  The ficus plant gives my father a chance to get out of his office and to exercise more than once a week.  I also will have a chance to spend time with him, my brother, and my dog when he has taken me to visit his father."  A: A and B share the birthday;B: C and D do;E: F and G do;F: I and J do;G: K and L do.Output: 5

There are two common types of answers: "Yes" and "Answer the question," which gives an implied answer, but is not a true answer to the question. An answer that provides specific, concrete details (an answer to a question) is a true answer; an answer that specifically answers a single and specific question is simply a true answer that does not provide adequate details. The best solution to the problem of finding the best definition of an answer would be for the student to first answer the open-ended question. Then, by choosing a single, concise definition of an answer which can be used on the next open-ended question, the student would achieve his overall goal of finding the best answer.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Why is waiting for the doctor difficult for people who need to do work? Choices:  A: having appointements B: being late C: have time to think D: time consuming E: impatience<n>Output:		 24<n><n>### Introduction:<n>This is a discussion about waiting for someone to call you.  The first thing you need to do is make sure you are well informed and have all the information you need before you write anything to the doctor.  The second thing is to prepare questions to ask, so you know how to proceed at the moment you are called.  The next thing is to plan and follow through.  The last thing is to write any comments.  The questions that you need to know are:<n>1. Does the doctor want to check with you?<n>2. Does the doctor want the bill?<n>3. Does the doctor want a date?<n>4. Does the doctor want all of your records?<n>5. Does the doctor want his or her name on your record?<n>6. Does the doctor want copies of your records?<n>7. Does the doctor want you to check the bill?<n>8. Is this doctor your usual doctor? If you have been to this doctor before, you should know his or her name.  If it is your first visit to him or her and you are not sure, you can always ask the doctor for his or her telephone number on file.  If you are unsure, call your nurse at the office, but make sure that you have all the information you can get before calling.<n><n>You do not need to know the information about scheduling appointments (where you will be, the doctor's office on which you will be, etc.).  You should plan to leave this information out of any letter you write to this doctor.<n><n>If you need more time to call the doctor, you need to prepare questions ahead of time.<n><n>The instructions below take the reader through the following steps.  You may need to add a few things as you go through them, but these are pretty standard procedures.<n><n>Make a quick decision on what to say when you call and what to write down.<n><n>Prepare a paragraph list.<n><n>Plan the letter.<n><n>Plan the call.<n><n>Prepare to write the letter and write down what you are going to say.<n><n>Write the letter when you are on your way to the doctor's office.<n><n>Write the phone number of your nurse.<n><n>Write the name of the doctor.<n><n>If your doctor's name is in your doctor's letter or you do not know it, call the nurse and ask for the doctor's phone number.<n><n>Write the information that you

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What is another term for instituting civil action? Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n>Output:		 C<n><n>In the case of civil action: It can be a form of regulation or statute. The other terms are confused. In the case of riot: There might be rioters, but there is no legislation. When there is a confusion about a word, there should be a rule or a law. There are many problems with that rule and law, see, for example, a student's refusal to write a required response to a test. When there is a riot: there will be a police force, and if those forces are ineffective then there will be violence on the streets. When there is a police force and they are ineffective, there will be riots.<n><n>In the case where there is confusion: That confusion is a problem within the field of government. (See also the word confusion: A student who uses incorrect language in a text book.)<n><n>Which word is correct: Confusion? Or confusion.? There may be confusion in the field of government. If there is confusion within the government it means that there is confusion with respect to the government as a whole, or that there are several different levels of government.<n><n>In the context of the word confusion, the definition is "something that causes confusion." There is a lack of clarity about government itself, at least between the two basic levels of government, the Executive and the Legislative. Because of the lack of clarity there may be multiple levels of government as there have been many over the years. As there has been multiple levels of government there have been multiple definitions of government with its own rules and regulations. There has also been confusion over which of the various levels of government is the proper level for government.<n><n>In a case where there is confusion within government there is the danger of a form of confusion between laws or regulations being applied to all levels of government and not just to one level, and there is the fear of confusion between law and regulations being applied to those regulations that do not apply to those regulations being applied to others that do apply, and thus causing a confusion about which laws apply, or which rules apply. That is another name for confusion. See also confusion: A student who gives incorrect answers to tests.<n><n>The confusion is also the danger of politicians interpreting laws in ways that make people more comfortable with government. And this gives an advantage to government, but also, a disadvantage.<n><n>Examples of examples of confusion: For example, politicians could want to make it more difficult for people to have guns. This is because guns are a threat to governments because

On days that I feel bad I make it a point not to do things that make me feel like crap. 3.When I feel bad I don’t talk much, I am more interested in books, movies, music.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What city in the middle east is known for a temple? Choices:  A: jerusalem B: texas C: middle east D: china E: india<n>Output:		 How many states are in the middle east?<n><n>Input:A: 1 B: 2 C: 1 D: 2<n>Output: 11<n><n>Input:The following statements are true:  1) The city of Tijuana has a beautiful river, which makes it desirable for summer residents. 2) Sticker placement is considered the best way to communicate important messages. 3) There are almost always 3 stickers on the front of a journal. 4) A sticker, with a simple message, will often stay with a user for a long time. For example, people may use stickers, and then a week later, they may lose the sticker and throw it away. 5) The more complex stickers are considered more valuable and more likely to cause confusion. 6) An increase in sticker value is caused by the fact that stickers are a small part of the total cost of buying a new journal. 7) The importance of stickers becomes diluted when there are too many stickers. 8) When stickers are added to a journal, it often increases the value of a journal by 10%.<n><n>Input:A city in Brazil is noted for an important government building which houses embassies, and a well-known museum with many priceless pieces of art. Choices: 1) Rio de Janeiro 2) São Paulo 3) Fortaleza 4) Brasília 5) Recife<n>Output: 44<n>(1) 1) 8(2) 1) 6(3) 10(4) 11(5) 7(2) 0(4) 14(10) 21(12) 25(6) 15(3)<n><n>This problem is a real life example of what psychologists believe can drive people to buy or rent a home. In real life, the market is flooded from many options. This is called market saturation. In order to succeed in the market, many buyers find it difficult, if not impossible, to narrow down to a specific house, or they have no choice of choosing a specific house when they go to the real estate agent to find a place to live. In this problem, the buyer has to look at the properties in the middle of many options to find the perfect house.<n><n>Input:The population of the world is estimated to be around 7 billion. But the question is:  (M) and (E) are correct since they are the only answer that uses "k".<n><n>In the context of what the teacher says about the questions, the teacher means that you are correct if you put a "K" before "lips" in your answer.<n><n>The teacher then puts (M) and (D) in the same category because she has to put something for both types of lip, but she could say:<n><n>The teacher then says that the word "k" on it's own doesn't count, but you have to put something for it in the answer, e.g. (D) is allowed to say "k" by itself even without a "K", but that is not allowed for "M".<n><n>That's what the teacher meant when she said that (M) and (A) are incorrect and (E) and (B) are right.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. Questions are graded for correctness and comprehension.<n><n>Questions contain:<n><n>Multiple Choice<n>Name: 1 - Answer 2<n><n>1 - 2a.  Is the name of the item in the first set of questions the name of the item on the 3rd set? A:? B: ? C: ? D:<n><n>a.  1-2b.  1-4c.  1-5d.  2a-2b4<n>2a - 2b4d.  1-4<n>1-5<n><n>The last section of the game is an all-subjects practice exercise which can be used during the entire lesson. It is graded, so if you are going to use this activity with children with different levels of competence, you'll want to check the levels at the beginning of the lesson.<n><n>Questions consist of 7 choices with a grade of 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5. Each question is indicated in the first column for the correct answer. Your grade will be based upon your answer of the question.<n><n>When answering questions, try to remember that there are two possibilities. If you answered the question correctly but the incorrect answer was the correct answer, you will get a 3 and vice versa. For example, if you answer the question correctly and your answer was "C", get a 3. If you answered the answer correctly and your answer was 2, get a 3. Each choice is 2 or 3, so both choices are correct. The correct choice is marked with a star for the grade. For each incorrect choice, get a 1. Your grade is the correct answer or "C". Select the correct option if available. Please answer all questions correctly for each choice to achieve a high score.<n><n>Once the questions for the lesson of this lesson are completed, they must be turned in. The answers need to be turned in by a single child so that we can complete the test at the end of each lesson. A parent must accompany the student to turn in the answers. A parent or other responsible adult must also turn in the homework at the end of the lesson to complete this test.<n><n>Students must turn in the homework no more than an hour before their scheduled study hall time, so it is recommended that all homework be turn in at least 3 hours before the beginning of the scheduled study
