### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:If you're standing in line and the line isn't moving what might you feel? Choices:  A: order B: queueing up C: wait turn D: fatigue E: anger<n>Output:		<n><n>Input: If you have to stand in line at Disneyland for three hours what comes to mind first? Choices: A: people running by B: people not running C: people talking D: people eating/drinking E: music being played F: people eating popcorn<n>Output:<n><n>You can use the same response option two times.<n><n>In this game the number of questions is randomly selected for each user and the points are distributed in different ways to achieve different levels of difficulty. The levels are -1 (no questions, no points), -2 (no questions, no point 1 and 2), -3 (no questions, no award and no points), -4 (no questions, no reward and no points), and -5 (no questions. Point number 5 can be scored up or down).
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n>Output:		 None<n><n>Input: What happens to all the plastic bags given away by grocery stores? Choices:  The plastic bag is thrown away  The bag is given to a nearby store so the next customer can receive it  The bag is kept for a week or is recycled<n>Output: None<n>Input: What has to be done in the first place to help the environment? Choices:  Reduce the use of plastic products.  Encourage use of reusable products.  Encourage recycle products.  Encourage composting<n>Output: None<n>This is a game to understand if people make choices, or if they are simply waiting on an auto-response.<n><n>In this game, customers can decide whether to spend money, send money, or send money to a merchant. People with fewer than 5 stickers, and businesses without a sticker count, need to make choices.<n><n>For example, some customers like to collect souvenirs, others use sticky notes to communicate to their cashiers or managers (e.g., “don’t throw out our stickers”). Businesses could choose to send customers a postcard at the checkout with specific information regarding a specific sticker’s placement and use, or could provide a form for customers to take before shopping that lists the stickers they intend to use, allowing them to place stickers as needed.<n><n>In other words, stickers are a tool that businesses and customers can use to communicate with each other.<n><n>This game is very powerful because the choices can be used for the following different situations:  The stickers can be used to communicate with customers  The stickers are for their convenience and can be used to communicate directly with managers of businesses.<n>A sticker that you leave behind for a month or more at a store can indicate that you will not be returning to that store.<n>The stickers can be used by managers of stores to communicate their preferences for certain goods and services.<n><n>See also<n><n>Answers:<n><n>A: The tags do not get picked up at the store.<n>B: Customers must decide which stickers are for them and which will be given to others.<n>C: The manager is in the store and wants customers to understand the manager’s intentions to customers.<n>D: Customers do business with business owners.<n>E: There is a long queue at the store.<n><n>References<n><n>External links<n> The Sticker Game

Output: 44<n><n>Input - An  illegitimate designer is a designer who uses an item of clothing that was not made by a legitimate designer.  Outlet - The second-hand clothing shop sells products made by other people.  If  the shop does not offer a guarantee as is customary, how can  the retailer be sure you are not getting a counterfeit or a poorly made garment?  Example  The store will:   1) check the number of stitches on all the stitching on the clothing 2) check the construction with respect to the material 3) ask for a certificate from the fabric maker for its authenticity.<n> Outlet - A designer sells clothing at  a department store retail outlet.  The outlet sells clothing that was not made using his or her own fabrics.  The store does not offer a guarantee, either as to quality or as to the legality of the clothing.<n><n>You may not edit the source code without assigning the correct type of value to the appropriate property.<n><n>There were 3 people in a line and two of them had the same number of stickers.  All told, the person to your right has 89 stickers, your right-most neighbor has 48 stickers, and your next left-most neighboring neighbor has 34 stickers.  This way, you can compare how many stickers are left for every sticker of 3 people.<n><n>Assignment 4 - Asserting a property in OSCONDS.ORG does not mean the property is actually there. Rather, the property must be a value that has special meaning, such as a particular number.  The property must then be a valid property in ORG's Object Specification. (The purpose of the property is to demonstrate the use of the specification for real objects.)<n><n>Input:Asserting a property in ORG does not mean the object is present. Rather, the property (a number) must be a distinct value that can be assigned to an object.  The property must be a valid property in the Object Specification. (It is not necessary for the value to refer to the object. For example, you could assign the value "1" to the object "1").<n><n>Output:Asserting the property "1" within an object, in effect declares the object a distinct, known, identifiable item

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:If I need deodorant, where do I go to but some? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n>Output:		 49<n><n>Output:What color is a rainbow? Choices:  Yellow  Green  Blue  Red  White  Violet (2 shades)<n>Output: 36<n><n>The problem involves the use of the word "curious". In the real world, "curious" is a word one rarely hears. Most people are simply "asking" questions. When we say "curious", we mean "looking for answers to unknown questions". A real-life "curious" person is always seeking knowledge for their next step. That is different from a "curious" student in class who might be studying to get the answer to a test question, and thus studying their subject for class. The "curious" student is not necessarily seeking knowledge. "Curious" is how a particular person is interpreting a situation.<n>I think I understand how this sort of inquiry would help a student study a specific topic. However, I am not comfortable writing this sort of assignment. What is your opinion?

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:She had a knack for entertaining, everybody told he she had a what? Choices:  A: fun B: talent C: learn about D: intelligence E: recognize<n>Output:		 54<n><n>In both cases you have to figure out the number of stickers remaining to figure out Mary's total and to compare that total to the total she received.<n><n>Solution:<n><n>Assume Mary gave a total of 89 stickers and that there are 6 other pages of journal that have stickers that require Mary to take 89 stickers. Now that she has 89 remaining and no pages of journal with stickers that require more stickers, Mary has 74 stickers remaining. Since Mary has 70 stickers remaining and has no pages of journal with sticker requirements requiring more stickers, her total is 71.<n><n>Assume the answer was 54.<n><n>If no sticker pages are required, Mary has 90 stickers remaining. If the answer was 54, then 90*2 = 54 = 110 stickers remain.

When thinking about it in terms of the whole number of stickers you have remaining, it is important to realize that each sticker has their own weight. Each sticker weighs roughly one-hundredths of an ounce, so it is difficult to apply a percentage value to a sticker.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Always wash your hands before eating, you don't want to get germs onto food and inside your what? Choices:  A: water B: doctor C: spread disease D: mouth E: ear<n>Output:		 You have 43 stickers.<n><n>I forgot to mention that she always gets the stickers from me.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>She has 44 stickers because she has three large stickers on the front and one large sticker each to 6 other pages, while only getting 47 stickers each from me (one sticker each to 4 other pages). This is because she uses 3 large stickers on the<n>front and 7 stickers from me (one large sticker each to 6 pages) to the 4 other pages, which adds up to 44. So:<n><n>Number Of Hand Wash Stickers Required:<n><n>44 Hand Wash Stickers<n><n>Assumptions (Optional):<n><n>1) Each student is different from the next, so your answer may vary from the exact number.<n><n>2) If Mary was using a normal marker pen (like the Moleskine), her answer would be 44 stickers.<n><n>3) If Mary was using the Moleskine pen in her hand, the stickers on the same page would be the same. In this case, you could only use 4 stickers on the page. If she was using a crayon (or other small pencil), then she has<n>45.<n><n>4) If Mary used a crayon, she has 45 stickers remaining.<n><n>5) If Mary was using crayons, each different color contains the same amount of stickers as she uses in one page. Therefore, she would not need 4 stickers on the other page to complete her homework, as you can see on the video.<n><n>6) If Mary was using dry erase markers (like the A4) and only used the dry erase markers in her hand to add more dots to each line, then she has 43 stickers remaining.

What did Mary say?output: 2<n><n>In this game, each player gets two identical books. They are in a triangle with a common point. Which one of the stories can you relate?<n>Answer the questions and get all of the answers in the form of a game. You can write them for yourself or play the game for others.<n><n>Each player gets five cards out of each pack. Each card has a short picture and a long text. Each text is a line from an appropriate story.<n><n>Each player draws a number on their card. For example, each player drew 6 cards and got 4 numbers.<n>The bottom number is written onto their card.<n><n>Players write down the short text on their card. They are not allowed to copy the text from the next player's card.<n>There is no particular order of writing on the cards. The story is completely random and players can do whatever they want.<n><n>Write any description of the story in the form of a sentence, sentence fragment or paragraph.<n><n>Players have to choose the story that is most interesting to them from the list.<n>If they choose the same story twice, they both get points for it.<n>If they choose a different story, they each get 1 point for their story.<n>If they end the game with the same stories, they each get 1 bonus point.<n><n>Choose the three most interesting stories to play the game.<n>Each player gets to write a sentence description on the card as an alternative to picking the correct story.<n><n>The person with the most points wins the game.<n><n>Example of the correct story:<n>- “My husband was having a boring day and decided to go shopping with me and my friend. I had told my friend in advance that I liked shopping.”<n><n>You may write stories about your own children or other adults.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Where do you buy a glass of wine? Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n>Output:		 The answer is E. This time you can make a little distinction.  I assume that  you have to go to the church to buy a drink, because that is where Mary's "blessing of wine" was at, thus making her "wine".<n><n>Input: The average male has a penis 10 in. long and a penis 7 in. at the head.  The average female has a penis 8 in. long and an average female penis 4 in. at the head..  What are the dimensions of the average vaginal canal?<n>Output: 9.5 x 14.3 inches<n><n>Input:Mary had 8 stickers on her desk labeled "To the best of my knowledge" and 6 other stickers labeling herself either "Prayers" or "Aunt" or something like that.  She used 4 large stickers on the front and 2 large stickers on the back.  Which 4 stickers is Mary using  in which page of her notebook?<n><n>Output: Mary has 7 stickers on her desk.  She used 3 small and 3 large stickers.  This time she can make a distinction.  There is no way that Mary used 4 small stickers on her desk.<n><n>Input: A teacher in the back of the class gave permission to someone to bring a picture in a jar to show the class.  It was taken in a snow globe, with a snowflake in the window.  What does the teacher say about this?<n>Output: 8<n><n>(a. a) A teacher in the back<n>(b. a) The teacher<n>(c) The students<n>(d) No one<n>(e) Yes one<n><n>Example:<n><n>Input:  Mary and Mary met at a local art show. Mary told Mary, "I think I will go with Barbara tonight." Mary, who was not in the shop, got to buy some wine from  at the show.<n><n>Output: Barbara was "one" of Mary's three dates for tonight. She told Mary, "It was a real nice meeting. I really like Mary."<n><n>Input: I took my girlfriend to a local art show.  She told me, "I really like your work."  And she showed me her art.<n><n>Output: I could not take her home because I am very busy tonight and I would have no time to go to another art show with her.<n><n>Input:Mary wrote in her diary that she saw two women who she thought she "knew".
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. Brad ordered pancakes  and french toast C: cheese D: throwing up E: just eating<n>Output:  It is breakfast time.  Brad gets coffee  A: tossup B: throwup C: no good D: throwing up E : wine<n>Output:  Brad got pancakes and french toast.  He drinks coffee  A: toss up  B: tossup  C: no good  D: tossup  E: toss up<n>Output:   There was no syrup involved<n>A = toss up B = tossup C C is better and he didn't take food  D D is a cheese  E E is better and he didn’t take food   E = toss up
